overview: The purpose of this measure is to require that pharmacy technicians be registered with and obtain a certificate of registration issued by the Board of Pharmacy, beginning January 1, 2026. [16] The bill imposes a duty on pharmacists-in-charge to report violations by registered pharmacy technicians to the Board of Pharmacy. [16] It also specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians and pharmacy interns. [16]
appropriations: The provided legislative documents do not contain any specific appropriations for this measure. [15] Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by deleting the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK_66, NUMBER_0] The bill does not specify any intended uses for funding. [15]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided documents do not contain financial projections or a detailed cost estimation methodology. [15] The bill establishes that any person who violates the provisions of the chapter shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2] However, there is no methodology provided to estimate the revenue from these fines. [15]
agency_impact: The Board of Pharmacy will be required to issue certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [15] A new duty is imposed on the pharmacist-in-charge to notify the board, in writing, if a registered pharmacy technician is suspected to have violated any law or rule regarding the practice of pharmacy. [15] The board may also deny, revoke, or suspend any registration for causes including professional misconduct or violation of federal or state drug laws. [15]
economic_impact: This measure establishes financial penalties for non-compliance. [15] Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter or the rules adopted pursuant to this chapter shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2] The documents do not specify any other direct economic impacts, cost savings, or benefits to the community. [15]
policy_impact: This measure amends Chapter 461, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to establish a registration requirement for pharmacy technicians, which did not previously exist. [15] It specifies that supervising registered pharmacists are responsible for the actions of registered pharmacy technicians. [15] The bill also clarifies that the supervising registered pharmacist shall supervise the actions of the pharmacy intern. [15]
revenue_sources: This measure has been amended to delete the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians, removing a potential source of revenue. [CHUNK_66, NUMBER_0] The only potential revenue source identified in the bill is from disciplinary fines. [15] These fines shall be no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The provided documents do not include a six-year fiscal projection. [15] A previous funding mechanism has been removed by deleting the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK_66, NUMBER_0] This change eliminates a recurring revenue stream that would have supported the program. [16] A new, but variable, revenue stream is created through fines for violations. [15] Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2] The number of registrants and potential violations is unknown, so future revenue cannot be projected. [15] Certificates of registration will be valid through December 31 of each odd-numbered year, indicating a biennial renewal cycle, but without a fee. [15] The administrative costs to the Board of Pharmacy for managing the registration and renewal process are not specified. [15] The bill does not mention any changes to staffing levels. [15] The long-term fiscal sustainability of the program without a dedicated funding source is not addressed. [16]
operating_revenue_impact: The measure will have a mixed impact on operating revenues. [15] A potential, recurring revenue stream was eliminated by deleting the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK_66, NUMBER_0] However, the bill creates a new, albeit unpredictable, source of revenue by establishing fines of no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation of the chapter. [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2]
capital_expenditure_impact: The provided legislative documents do not indicate any capital expenditures are required for this measure. [15] No investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure are mentioned in the bill. [15] The purpose of the measure is to establish a regulatory system for pharmacy technicians. [15]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The provided documents do not specify any ongoing fiscal obligations after a six-year period. [15] The registration program for pharmacy technicians is permanent, but with the deletion of the registration fee, there is no specified recurring funding source to cover long-term administrative costs. [16] Potential revenue from fines is unpredictable and may not be sufficient to sustain the program. [15]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The primary update from the previous fiscal note is the change in the measure's funding mechanism and effective date. [16] Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by deleting the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK_66, NUMBER_0] The measure now includes a provision that any person who violates the chapter shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation, which was not previously specified. [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2] Additionally, the committee changed its effective date to upon approval, replacing the previous placeholder date. [16]
fte_positions: The provided legislative documents for H.B. 72, C.D. 1 do not specify the addition or modification of any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions. [15] There is no mention of new staffing required by the Board of Pharmacy to implement or manage the new registration program. [15] The bill's focus is on establishing the regulatory requirements for pharmacy technicians. [15]
appropriations_changes: Consistent with the previous version, the current bill does not contain any appropriations. [15] A significant change is that a potential funding mechanism has been explicitly removed. [16] The Committee on Conference amended the measure by deleting the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians. [CHUNK_66, NUMBER_0]
funding_sources_changes: There is a significant change in funding sources from what was previously considered. [16] The Committee on Conference has deleted the $20 (HB72_CD1_CCR182_.htm.txt) registration fee for pharmacy technicians, which removes a key funding source. [CHUNK_66, NUMBER_0] The bill now establishes a new potential revenue source through fines, stating that any person who violates the chapter shall be fined no less than $100 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) and no more than $1,000 (HB72_CD1_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [CHUNK_56, NUMBER_1, NUMBER_2]
department_impact: The impacted department remains the same as in the previous version. [15] The Board of Pharmacy, under the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs, is responsible for issuing certificates of registration for registered pharmacy technicians. [15] The board is also responsible for disciplinary actions, including denying, revoking, or suspending any registration. [15]
reports_required: The bill requires pharmacists-in-charge to report certain violations to the Board of Pharmacy. [16] If a registered pharmacy technician is suspected to have violated any law or rule regarding the practice of pharmacy, legend drugs, or controlled substances, the pharmacist-in-charge shall notify the board in writing. [15] The documents do not specify any new reports to be submitted to the legislature. [15]
pilot_program: This measure does not create a pilot program. [15] It establishes a permanent requirement that, beginning January 1, 2026, no person shall act as a pharmacy technician without first obtaining a valid certificate of registration. [15] The bill does state that the Board of Pharmacy may approve pilot and demonstration research projects for innovative applications in the practice of pharmacy. [15]
sunset_date: The provided documents do not contain a sunset date for the bill. [15] Section 26H-6, Hawaii Revised Statutes, which relates to the repeal of professional and vocational regulatory boards and commissions, shall not apply to this Act. [15]
effective_date: The effective date has been changed from a previous placeholder date. [16] The Conference Committee amended this measure by changing its effective date to upon approval. [16] Section 11 of the bill states, "This Act shall take effect upon its approval." [15]
